title: How to start writing creative things - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the harder question is why rather than how. How: you sit down and write. If you don’t have any ideas, brainstorm, or look at some of the techniques suggested all over Quora. How do I come up with ideas to write about? I am sitting here, staring at the wall. No ideas are coming. Don’t forget to look at the suggested questions related to the above question. They’re on the right side of your screen. There are loads of them that will help you. If you have trouble finding your ‘voice’ or you’re not sure how to turn an idea into a story, there are loads of books about this. One that I like to suggest is: Amazon.com: Plot Versus Character: A Balanced Approach to Writing Great Fiction (0035313650352): Jeff Gerke: Books There’s also: Amazon.com: Story: Style, Structure, Substance, and the Principles of Screenwriting eBook: Robert McKee: Kindle Store But some people find that one too complicated. I think a beginner can do fine with it if they’re a careful reader and don’t insist on ‘getting’ all the information into their heads the first time they read it. It’s best to read some, write some, read some more … it’s a great book to reread because you’ll get something new out of it each time you make progress with your writing craft. But maybe you need this Quora thread for the how: I want to write a novel, but don't have an appealing story idea, skill as a writer, free time, tenacity, imagination, or observational skill needed to write a good novel. What should I do? None of this advice will make a bit of difference, though, unless you figure out why you want to write. Is it for fun? Do you want to develop a side income stream? Do you have things you want to say to the world? Are you a masochist? (The last comment is meant to be funny. I feel like a masochist sometimes because of my compulsion to write.) Until you have a purpose, whether it’s self-entertainment, therapy, you want to work toward becoming a professionally published author, or some other reason, it’s going to be hard to direct your efforts. It’s also going to be hard to give you specific advice that will be useful for you. I hope this helps!

If you mean by “creative” the same thing I mean by “creative,” you’ve already started, merely by creating that one sentence question? You could have asked it in dozens of different ways, or not ask it at all, but you created it. Some people think that fiction is synonymous with “creative,” but they’re only looking at the writer’s skill with words. Yes, flowery, evocative words can make some fine writing, but that’s not all there is to creativity in writing. Any time you write something that’s never been written before, you’re creating. In fact, the only writing I can think of that’s not “creative” is plagiarism. In fiction, for example, you are being creative when you choose which scenes to write and which to omit. But you do the same thing in writing non-fiction. If you’re writing, say, about World War II, which battles do you choose to write about? What non-battle events do you describe? And how many details of each do you write, and which do you omit. Those are all “creative things.” No two accounts of World War II will be the same. Each will be a “creative thing.” Then, too, it’s creative to decide on the order of things in you writing. Where does the story of a romance begin? Where does the story of World War II begin? Do you choose chronological order in your writing, or do you go back and forth in time? If two events take place concurrently, which do you place first in your writing? Or perhaps you switch back and forth with a little of one alternating with a bit of the other? In other words, any time you write anything that’s not merely copying someone else’s words, you writing a “creative thing.” So, just stop worrying about creativity and start writing. Good luck! Weinberg on Writing: The Fieldstone Method
